III. INVESTIGATION
Rule Code Criminal history check, subject to requirements; staff
Title qualifications
Rule Code & CCI Rule 400.4112
Section (4) A person with ongoing duties shall have both of the following:
Description (a) Ability to perform duties of the position assigned.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation Former Youth J told Complainant female Staff 1 wrestled with him.
Investigation Documents reviewed:
DCWL received this complaint on 3/7/24.
I reviewed MISACWIS on 3/7/24 which was not updated and
indicated Youth J never resided at Wolverine Center. Intake
information indicates Former Youth J has borderline cognitive
functioning.
Interviews:
I contacted Complainant/Youth J’s PAFC Worker on 3/7/24 via
phone, left a voice message and did not receive a response.
I interviewed Staff 1 via Teams on 3/11/24. She has worked at
the facility for six months. Staff 1 recalled working with Former
Youth J at Wolverine Center when he required 2:1 staffing (two
staff assigned to one youth). She described him as tall,
cognitively impaired, hot-headed, out-of-control, and aggressive
toward other youths. When Youth J was downgraded to 1:1
staffing, Staff 1 said the youth kept asking that she be his
assigned 1:1 staff. “I did it once or twice then refused. I’m small. I
can’t hold him back. He called me ‘mom’ and I told him not to call
me that. He would touch my shoulder and move into my personal
space.” Staff 1 said when Former Youth J would get into her
personal space, she would redirect him not to touch her and
asked him to stand 3-feet away. “Sometimes he would listen and
sometimes not…Another reason why I did not want to be assigned
to him was because he was acting like he wanted me to be his
girlfriend.” Staff 1 denied ever wrestling with Former Youth J.
She said she decided it was best to set firm boundaries with him,
which she did.
2

I interviewed Staff 2 on 4/11/24 via phone. He has worked at the
facility for six months. Staff 2 recalled seeing Staff 1 supervising
Youth J. “I never saw her horseplaying, wrestling or anything with
him.” Staff 2 described Staff 1 as someone who is “firm and
knows how to verbally de-escalate youth.” Staff 2 recalled he
once overheard Youth J refer to Staff 1 as “auntie.” “Staff 1 told
him, ‘My name is Staff 1. Youth can’t call me auntie.’” Asked to
describe Former Youth J, Staff 2 said he had poor boundaries and
wanted to be friends with all of the staff. “He called me ‘bro’ and I
told him to call me Staff 2.”
Former Youth J was interviewed by Consultant 2 and Area
Manager at his current placement on 4/18/24. He stated Staff 1 at
Wolverine Center is like his mom. Former Youth J stated he
never fought or wrestled with Staff 1.
Analysis There is no evidence of inappropriate boundaries or behavior on
the part of Staff 1 related to Former Youth J.
Conclusion Violation Not Established
Rule Code Discharge plan
Title
Rule Code & CCI Rule 400.4166
Section (2) For an unplanned discharge, an institution shall provide a brief
Description summary or other documentation of the circumstances
surrounding the discharge.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation Facility did not send Former Youth J’s medication with him when
he was arrested by police on 2/25/24.
Investigation Documents reviewed:
For an unplanned discharge, Rule 400.4166 does not require an
institution to send his medication with him during a police arrest or
to deliver a youth’s medication or belongings to his next
placement.
Wolverine does not have a policy indicating medications and
belongings are to be sent with the youth or police at the time of an
arrest or unplanned discharge.
3

I reviewed the Foster Care/Juvenile Justice Action Summary
dated 3/5/24 which indicates Former Youth J was arrested by
police at Wolverine Center on Sunday 2/25/24, which is
considered an unplanned discharge.
I reviewed email correspondence dated 3/1/24 between
Complainant/Youth J’s PAFC Worker and Wolverine Case
Manager. Complainant/Youth J’s PAFC Worker asked if any of
Former Youth J’s belongings needed to be picked up and
Wolverine Case Manager indicated his medication needed to be
picked up.
Interviews:
Consultant 2 interviewed Youth J at the Wayne County Juvenile
Detention Center on 3/7/24 and he told her he had not received
his medication.
I contacted Complainant/Youth J’s PAFC Worker via phone on
3/7/24, left a voice message and did not receive a response. A
PCU call occurred on 3/14/24 during which Complainant/PAFC
Worker stated she had not picked up Former Youth J’s medication
yet and believed it was still at Wolverine Center. DHHS and
DCWL personnel informed Complainant/PAFC Worker that it is
her responsibility to go to Wolverine Center, pick up Youth J’s
medication and take it to his new placement as this was an
unplanned discharge and he had already gone without his
medication for 18 days. Complainant/ PAFC Worker stated she
would pick up the medication sometime the following week.
Analysis Consistent with the discharge plan licensing rule, the facility
provided a brief summary of the circumstances surrounding
Former Youth J’s unplanned discharge from Wolverine Center on
2/25/24 in a Foster Care Juvenile Justice Action summary dated
3/5/24.
It was Complainant/PAFC Worker’s responsibility, not Wolverine’s,
to pick up Former Youth J’s medication and deliver it to his next
placement.
Wolverine Center does not have a policy indicating medications
and belongings are to be sent with the youth or police at the time
of an arrest or unplanned discharge.
Conclusion Violation Not Established
